mods.abstract: John Lewis speaking at a 1961 workshop at Highlander on the organization of the Nashville Sit-In movement. He emphasizes the democratic makeup of the movement.

John Lewis was a Civil Rights leader and United States Congressman from Georgia. Lewis graduated from American Baptist Theological Seminary and Fisk University in Nashville. As a student he helped organize the Nashville Sit-Ins to successfully desegregate Nashville's lunch counters. He was among the original 13 Freedom Riders and served as Chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) from 1963-1966. He helped lead the Selma to Montgomery marches and was nearly killed on March 7, 1965, when an officer fractured his skull with a club. He served as chairman of the Voter Education Project from 1970-1977 when he was first ran for Congress. After serving in the Carter administration Lewis was elected to serve Georgia's 5th Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives. Lewis's Civil Rights work continued while in Congress. He died on July 17, 2020.
